Functions and plot_ly figures from Flight Data

The following is an assignment I completed which includes sorting a data set to find the desired data, creating functions which can then be reused later, and finally creating figures to represent the data.

Morelle Tinsley https://www.google.com
04-20-2021

Functions

  1. Create a function that will return the sum of 2 numbers.
two_two <- function(firstnum, secondnum){
  
  result <- sum(firstnum, secondnum) 
  
  return(result)
  }
two_two(2,2) #ran the code with two numbers

[1] 4
  1. Create a function that will return the mean of a vector of numbers fed to it.
    -You can see how I first created a function which would calculate a mean, and then later I input a vector of numbers, and the function found its mean for me.
mynumbers <- sample(1:100, 10)

mean_function <- function(vector){ 
  
  result <- mean(vector)
  
  return(result)
}

mean_vector <- c(7,19,245,300,50,89)


mean_function(mean_vector)

[1] 118.3333
  1. Now, expand on the function you made above, and instead of just returning the number, have it return the sentence:
    “The mean is ___” where the blank is the calculated result.
mean_vector <- c(7,19,245,300,50,89)

question3 <- function(vector.set) {
  avg.set <- mean(vector.set)
  print(paste("The mean is", avg.set))
}

question3(mean_vector)

[1] "The mean is 118.333333333333"
#load the data to use for the rest of the assignment questions
flights <- nycflights13::flights
  1. Using the flights dataset from the package nycflights13 loaded in the above cell, create a function that filters the data frame to only include records from a single originating airport (column name origin).
head(flights)

# A tibble: 6 x 19
   year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time
  <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>
1  2013     1     1      517            515         2      830
2  2013     1     1      533            529         4      850
3  2013     1     1      542            540         2      923
4  2013     1     1      544            545        -1     1004
5  2013     1     1      554            600        -6      812
6  2013     1     1      554            558        -4      740
# … with 12 more variables: sched_arr_time <int>, arr_delay <dbl>,
#   carrier <chr>, flight <int>, tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>,
#   dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>, hour <dbl>,
#   minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>
snglorgn <- function(flight_numbers) {
  flight_numbers %>%
    filter(origin == "JFK")
}

snglorgn(flights)

  1. Similarly, using the flights dataset, create a function that:
  • filters the data frame to only include records from a single originating airport (column name origin), and then
  • aggregates the results by airline (carrier) to show how many flights each airline has from that airport.
head(flights)

# A tibble: 6 x 19
   year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time
  <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>
1  2013     1     1      517            515         2      830
2  2013     1     1      533            529         4      850
3  2013     1     1      542            540         2      923
4  2013     1     1      544            545        -1     1004
5  2013     1     1      554            600        -6      812
6  2013     1     1      554            558        -4      740
# … with 12 more variables: sched_arr_time <int>, arr_delay <dbl>,
#   carrier <chr>, flight <int>, tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>,
#   dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>, hour <dbl>,
#   minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>
snglorgn <- function(flight_numbers) {
  flight_numbers %>%
    filter(origin == "JFK") %>% 
    count(carrier)
}


snglorgn(flights)

# A tibble: 10 x 2
   carrier     n
   <chr>   <int>
 1 9E      14651
 2 AA      13783
 3 B6      42076
 4 DL      20701
 5 EV       1408
 6 HA        342
 7 MQ       7193
 8 UA       4534
 9 US       2995
10 VX       3596
  1. Similarly, using the flights dataset, create a function that:
  • filters the data frame to only include records from a single originating airport (column name origin), and then
  • filter to only include flights longer than a specific number of minutes (air_time), and then
  • aggregates the results by airline (carrier) to show how many flights of that length each airline has from that airport.
head(flights)

# A tibble: 6 x 19
   year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time
  <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>
1  2013     1     1      517            515         2      830
2  2013     1     1      533            529         4      850
3  2013     1     1      542            540         2      923
4  2013     1     1      544            545        -1     1004
5  2013     1     1      554            600        -6      812
6  2013     1     1      554            558        -4      740
# … with 12 more variables: sched_arr_time <int>, arr_delay <dbl>,
#   carrier <chr>, flight <int>, tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>,
#   dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>, hour <dbl>,
#   minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>
snglorgn_plusmore <- function(flight_numbers) {
  flight_numbers %>%
    filter(origin == "JFK") %>% 
    filter(air_time>400) %>% 
    count(carrier)
}

snglorgn_plusmore(flights)

# A tibble: 6 x 2
  carrier     n
  <chr>   <int>
1 AA          6
2 B6          2
3 DL          7
4 HA        342
5 UA          4
6 VX          4

Plotly charts

  1. Using the flights dataset, use plotly to create a bar chart showing the breakdown of flights by airline that originate from JFK airport (origin) and are more than 400 minutes in length (air_time).

    • Now we have come to the portion of the assignment where we use sorting and functions to make graphics to show our data.

    • Below, you can see that I created a function which sorted my data, gave it a name, and then imput it into the Plot_ly chart which makes a bar chart from the newly filtered data.

head(flights)

# A tibble: 6 x 19
   year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time
  <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>
1  2013     1     1      517            515         2      830
2  2013     1     1      533            529         4      850
3  2013     1     1      542            540         2      923
4  2013     1     1      544            545        -1     1004
5  2013     1     1      554            600        -6      812
6  2013     1     1      554            558        -4      740
# … with 12 more variables: sched_arr_time <int>, arr_delay <dbl>,
#   carrier <chr>, flight <int>, tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>,
#   dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>, hour <dbl>,
#   minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>
snglorgn_plusmore <- function(flight_numbers) { #made a function to filter the data
  flight_numbers %>%
    filter(origin == "JFK") %>% 
    filter(air_time>400) %>% 
    count(carrier)}

snglorgn_plusmore(flights)

# A tibble: 6 x 2
  carrier     n
  <chr>   <int>
1 AA          6
2 B6          2
3 DL          7
4 HA        342
5 UA          4
6 VX          4
JFK_bar <- snglorgn_plusmore(flights)

plot_ly(data = JFK_bar,                    #create a bar chart from it
        x = ~carrier,
        y = ~n,
        type = "bar"
        ) %>% 
  layout(title = "400 minute flights by carrier from JFK",
         xaxis = list(title = "Carrier"),
         yaxis = list (title = "Number of flights"))
  1. Using the flights dataset, use plotly to create a bar chart showing which destination airports (dest) have the most flights with durations of over 400 minutes (air_time).
head(flights)

# A tibble: 6 x 19
   year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time
  <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>
1  2013     1     1      517            515         2      830
2  2013     1     1      533            529         4      850
3  2013     1     1      542            540         2      923
4  2013     1     1      544            545        -1     1004
5  2013     1     1      554            600        -6      812
6  2013     1     1      554            558        -4      740
# … with 12 more variables: sched_arr_time <int>, arr_delay <dbl>,
#   carrier <chr>, flight <int>, tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>,
#   dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>, hour <dbl>,
#   minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>
dest_count <- function(flight_numbers) {
  flight_numbers %>%
    filter(air_time>400) %>% 
    count(dest)}

dest_count(flights)

# A tibble: 7 x 2
  dest      n
  <chr> <int>
1 ANC       7
2 BUR       1
3 HNL     701
4 LAX       5
5 SAN       3
6 SFO      23
7 SNA       1
Dest_bar <- dest_count(flights)

plot_ly(data = Dest_bar,
        x =~dest,
        y = ~n,
        type = "bar") %>% 
  layout(title = "Destinations with most 400 minute flights",
         xaxis = list(title = "Destination"),
         yaxis = list (title = "Number of flights"))
  1. Using the flights dataset, use plotly to create a donut chart showing the share of flights each airline has for flights with a destination of Daniel K. Inouye International Airport (HNL) in Honolulu.
HNL_share <- function(flight_numbers){
  flight_numbers %>% 
    count(dest == "HNL")
}

head(flights)

# A tibble: 6 x 19
   year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time
  <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>
1  2013     1     1      517            515         2      830
2  2013     1     1      533            529         4      850
3  2013     1     1      542            540         2      923
4  2013     1     1      544            545        -1     1004
5  2013     1     1      554            600        -6      812
6  2013     1     1      554            558        -4      740
# … with 12 more variables: sched_arr_time <int>, arr_delay <dbl>,
#   carrier <chr>, flight <int>, tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>,
#   dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>, hour <dbl>,
#   minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>
flights %>% 
  filter(dest =="HNL") %>% 
  count(carrier) 

# A tibble: 2 x 2
  carrier     n
  <chr>   <int>
1 HA        342
2 UA        365
carrier_count <- function(data){
results <- data %>% 
    filter(dest == "HNL") %>% 
  count(carrier) 

return(results)
}

honolulu_donut <- carrier_count(flights)

fig <- honolulu_donut %>% plot_ly(labels = ~carrier, values = ~n)

fig <- fig %>% add_pie(hole = 0.6) #would make a pie chart, to make a donut chart add the hole

fig <- fig %>% layout(
                  title = "Number of HNL flights by carrier",  showlegend = F,
                  xaxis = list(showgrid = FALSE, zeroline = FALSE, showticklabels = FALSE),
                  yaxis = list(showgrid = FALSE, zeroline = FALSE, showticklabels = FALSE))
fig
  1. Using the flights dataset, use plotly to create a scatterplot chart for flights with a destination of Daniel K. Inouye International Airport (HNL) in Honolulu, that shows the relationship between the departure delay (dep_delay) and arrival delay (arr_delay).
head(flights)

# A tibble: 6 x 19
   year month   day dep_time sched_dep_time dep_delay arr_time
  <int> <int> <int>    <int>          <int>     <dbl>    <int>
1  2013     1     1      517            515         2      830
2  2013     1     1      533            529         4      850
3  2013     1     1      542            540         2      923
4  2013     1     1      544            545        -1     1004
5  2013     1     1      554            600        -6      812
6  2013     1     1      554            558        -4      740
# … with 12 more variables: sched_arr_time <int>, arr_delay <dbl>,
#   carrier <chr>, flight <int>, tailnum <chr>, origin <chr>,
#   dest <chr>, air_time <dbl>, distance <dbl>, hour <dbl>,
#   minute <dbl>, time_hour <dttm>
delay_data <- flights %>% 
  filter(dest == "HNL")

delay_plot_ly<- plot_ly(data = delay_data, x = ~dep_delay, y = ~arr_delay)

delay_scatter <- plot_ly(data = delay_data, x = ~dep_delay, y = ~arr_delay) %>% 
  layout(title = "Honolulu Arrival Delays According to Departure Delays")

delay_scatter
